An advantage of the empirical form developed above is that the parameter set ( M therm, τ decay, p) required to specify m therm and q therm is straightforwardly related to the set of parameters ( A, K, S, Z, w CH4, β) that describes the dimensions of the igneous sheet and the characteristics of the host rock. These are: A, the surface area of the sheet; Z, the depth of intrusion of the sheet below the contemporary seabed; S, the maximum thickness of the sheet; β, an exponent that describes how the sheet thins towards its edges; w CH4, the weight% organic matter expelled as carbon after thermal maturation; and K, the proportion labile:(labile + refractory) kerogen, where labile kerogen is the term for organic matter that initially produces oil which then cracks to gas, and refractory kerogen is the term for organic matter that produces gas directly
31 .
